sources.summary: Battle-tested Claude Code plugin providing production-ready configurations for agents, skills, hooks, commands, rules, and MCP setups. Represents comprehensive patterns from hackathon winner with focus on modular architecture, token optimization, and cross-session memory persistence.

key_concepts.description: Delegated task handlers with limited scope and tool access restrictions
Domain knowledge and methodology patterns organized hierarchically with automatic activation
Trigger-based automations firing on tool events for lifecycle management
Quick-execution workflows triggered via /command syntax
Mandatory guidelines stored in ~/.claude/rules/ for consistent behavior
Instinct-based learning with confidence scoring for pattern evolution
Progressive context refinement for subagents to optimize token usage
Automatic detection with 6-level priority cascade for cross-platform support

facts.claim: Claude Code v2.1+ auto-loads hooks/hooks.json by convention
Do NOT declare hooks in plugin.json to avoid duplicate detection errors
200k context window can shrink to 70k with too many tools enabled
Optimization rule: 20-30 MCPs configured, under 10 enabled per project, under 80 tools active
The Claude Code plugin system does not support distributing rules via plugins
TDD workflow: 1) Define interfaces first, 2) Write failing tests (RED), 3) Implement minimal code (GREEN), 4) Refactor (IMPROVE), 5) Verify 80%+ coverage

source.title: Understanding Claude Code: Full Stack Architecture
source.author: alexop.dev

sources.summary: Comprehensive guide explaining Claude Code's four-layer architecture: MCP (external integration), Core Features (memory, commands, subagents, hooks), Plugins (shareable configs), and Agent Skills (automatic capabilities). Focuses on practical integration patterns and multi-phase development workflows.

key_concepts.description: MCP → Core Features → Plugins → Agent Skills, each building on previous layer
Enterprise → User → Project → Folder cascading context system
Automatic (context-driven) vs Manual (explicit) vs Delegated (isolated) activation patterns
Command (shell execution - fast) vs Prompt (LLM-driven - flexible)
Monitor with /context, remove unused servers, optimize token consumption
Separate planning and implementation chats with /load-context for state transfer

facts.claim: CLAUDE.md load order: Enterprise → User (~/.claude/CLAUDE.md) → Project (./CLAUDE.md) → Folder (./src/components/CLAUDE.md)
MCP servers consume context window and should be monitored with /context command
MCP servers expose only their own tools unless explicitly provided Read, Write, or Bash access
Hooks have two operation modes: Command (fast, predictable shell execution) and Prompt (flexible, context-aware LLM decision-making)
Skills activate automatically based on description matching task context, loaded transparently without explicit invocation
CLAUDE.md should be kept as reference guide, not documentation

source.author: Shipyard Build

sources.summary: Practical reference guide covering skills framework, hooks automation, MCP integration, settings hierarchy, memory files, custom commands, subagents, and permission system. Focuses on configuration patterns and security best practices.

key_concepts.description: Skills invoke through natural language rather than explicit commands, allowing Claude to determine when to apply them
Pattern-based filtering for hook execution on specific file types or operations
User → Project → Local layered configuration with override capability
Global → Project root → Subdirectories context loading for persistent state
$ARGUMENTS variable for dynamic command execution with context injection
allowedTools and deny patterns for fine-grained security control

facts.claim: Skills invoke through natural language, allowing Claude to determine when to apply them, unlike slash commands that require explicit invocation
Hook events available: PreToolUse (can block), PostToolUse, UserPromptSubmit, SessionStart
Settings hierarchy with precedence: User settings (~/.claude/settings.json) → Project settings (.claude/settings.json) → Local settings (.claude/settings.local.json)
CLAUDE.md files provide persistent context loaded hierarchically: Global (~/.claude/CLAUDE.md) → Project root (./CLAUDE.md) → Subdirectories
CLAUDE.md approach reduces token consumption by eliminating repetitive context provision in prompts
Best practice: Review all changes before accepting, store sensitive data in .env files with explicit read denial, use .settings.local.json for personal configurations
